On the basis of the TAP system, an alternative to the traditional kinetic approach in heterogeneous catalysis is developed. This new approach, termed 'interrogative kinetics' involves a combination of two types of kinetic experiments called 'state-defining' (friendly) and 'state-altering' (typical) experiments. The state defining kinetic parameter, or 'kinetic parameter of the catalyst' (KPC) is proposed and compared with the kinetic characteristic 'turnover number'. The theory of TAP pulse response experiments is developed. Two deterministic models based on partial-differential equations are analyzed for the cases of diffusion, irreversible adsorption/reaction and reversible adsorption. The 'standard diffusion curve' that can be used for distinguishing the Knudsen flow regime is described, and simple criteria of the Knudsen regime are proposed. The concept of relative flow is described, and different fingerprints of TAP kinetics for irreversible adsorption/reaction and reversible adsorption are presented. TAP-2 experimental results on the selective oxidation of n-butane are used to illustrate the methodology of interrogative kinetics. "The important thing is not to stop questioning." Albert Einstein. Introduction Two general approaches, namely the 'practical catalyst' approach and the 'model catalyst' approach, are used in heterogeneous catalysis research. The 'practical catalyst' approach involves the systematic synthesis, testing and characterization of numerous catalyst samples, and is the basis for most industrial catalyst development. Bulk catalyst characterization techniques such as XRD, MR, etc. along with various physical measurements (i.e., surface areas, etc.) are used to characterize the bulk structure of practical catalysts. Industrial catalytic materials include supported metals, mixed metal oxides, and zeolites. Practical catalyst research has spurred the development of a variety of catalytic reactor systems, and a number of special reactors have been developed to obtain steady-state kinetics. Kinetic parameters are obtained from steady-state data by applying steady- 56 J. T. Cleaves et al. /Applied Catalysis A: General 160 (1997) 55-88 state reaction theory. These parameters are used extensively in the development of industrial catalytic processes, and to construct kinetic models of catalytic reactions. Although steady-state studies provide essential performance data for catalyst development, the apparent kinetics obtained from steady-state studies do not provide a detailed understanding of fundamental catalytic processes. In recent years nonsteadystate techniques such as temperature programmed desorption (TPD), temperature programmed reaction (TPR), isotopic switching, or pulse response experiments, have been developed to augment steady-state experiments. These techniques can provided a more detailed understanding of fundamental surface processes, but no detailed theory has been developed to obtain kinetic parameters from transient techniques. Currently, most `practical catalyst' development programs rely primarily on the application of traditional kinetic studies and structural analysis. The `model catalyst' approach has been used principally to investigate fundamental catalytic processes on well defined surfaces. Ultrahigh vacuum surface analytical techniques (AES, XPS, LEED, SIMS, etc.) are employed to characterize the catalytic surfaces at an atomic level, and reaction studies are carried out using thermal desorption spectroscopy TDS or molecular beam scattering experiments. One of the goals of the `model catalyst' approach is to obtain fundamental information on a variety of catalytic reactions which in turn can be used to guide the development of practical catalytic materials. However, correlating model catalyst research with practical catalyst research has not been straightforward, since there exists a significant `gap' between most `real world' catalytic processes, and the model reaction studies carried out in surface science systems. Practical catalytic reactions are generally performed at pressures at or above one atmosphere, whereas most surface analysis can be performed only in ultrahigh vacuum. This `gap' was first discussed by Bonzel [1] who coined the term `pressure gap'. In addition to being separated by a `pressure gap', practical and model catalyst studies are also separated by an even more significant `materials gap' that arises because of differences in the catalytic properties of practical and model catalysts. The `materials gap' is part of the larger chemical problem of how to correlate chemical structure with chemical activity. The `pressure-materials gap' issue has stimulated considerable discussion within the catalysis community, and a significant point of debate is whether results obtained on model catalysts at ultrahigh vacuum conditions can be extrapolated to real materials operating at higher pressures. In recent years, a number of approaches have been developed to overcome the `pressure-materials' gap. From the practical side, sophisticated surface science techniques have been adapted to study practical catalytic materials, and some progress has been made in characterizing the surface structure of real catalysts. From the other side, techniques that combine kinetic measurements on model catalysts at ambient pressures with pre- and post-reaction surface analysis have been used to investigate model reactions on model surfaces. These mutual efforts are ongoing, and it is anticipated that they will yield important new results. Notwithstanding significant progress in understanding many fundamental processes occurring in model catalytic systems, practical catalyst development is still a slow painstaking process hampered by a lack of fundamental information on the composition and structure of the catalytic phase or catalytic site. The surface of a practical catalyst is likely to be compositionally different from the bulk, structurally and compositionally nonuniform, and may change during the course of a catalytic reaction. As a result, information gleaned from determining the bulk crystal structure of a catalyst is of limited value in characterizing a catalyst surface. The chemical properties of a surface may also be strongly influenced by various adspecies which in turn may change during the course of a reaction. Adspecies, reaction intermediates, and adsorbed reaction products often have short surface lifetimes, and may exist in low concentration on the surface. As a result, they are difficult to detect and characterize under reaction conditions. Also, the catalytic sites on a practical catalyst may occupy only a small portion of the total catalyst surface making their identification difficult even with surface sensitive techniques. These factors pose serious obstacles to the direct observation and characterization of catalytic sites, and as a result it is difficult to develop detailed structure-activity correlations on practical catalysts. An alternative to the classic kinetic approach used in catalyst development, is a new approach that we have termed `interrogative kinetics' (IK). In contrast J.T Gleaves et al. /Applied Catalysis A: General 160 (1997) 55-88 to traditional steady-state kinetics which attempts to obtain kinetic parameters for a well determined 'steady-state' of the catalyst surface, interrogative kinetics attempts to systematically probe a variety of different states of the catalyst surface, and to understand how one state evolves into another. An important element of this approach is the rapid feedback between experiment and analysis that can be likened to a 'dialogue' between the researcher and the catalyst sample. The set of experiments that form an IK sequence represents a 'question' (e.g., how does a change in the oxidation state of a catalyst change its selectivity, or the activation energy of hydrocarbon conversion) that when answered leads to another question, and another IK sequence. Interrogative kinetics involves two types of experiments that are performed in sequence to reveal complex mechanisms and structure-activity relationships. The first type is a 'state-defining' (friendly) experiment that does not significantly perturb the kinetic state of the catalyst, but provides information that can characterize the state. The second type is a 'statealtering' (typical) experiment that perturbs the catalyst and changes its composition or structure in some predetermined fashion. To complete the sequence another state-defining experiment is performed to characterize the new state of the catalyst. State-defining experiments involve reactions of probe molecules with a catalyst, and provide kinetic parameters such as rate parameters of adsorption and desorption to characterize the reactions. One example of a 'probe reaction' is the irreversible chemisorption of a hydrocarbon on a metal oxide catalyst. In this case, the state-defining kinetic parameter of the reaction is the rate parameter of irreversible chemisorption, or the rate of irreversible chemisorption at unitary gas concentration. This parameter is state-defining because it depends on the kinetic state of the metal oxide surface. In particular, it depends on the concentration and reactivity of the surface species on which the hydrocarbon chemisorbs. Interrogative kinetics is based on the application of novel high speed transient response experiments (TAP pulse response experiments) [2,3] in conjunction with traditional kinetic measurements (steady-state, TPD, step-transient, etc.). IK uses a battery of kinetic measurements to probe the kinetic characteristics of a catalytic surface, and to monitor how these character- 57 istics change in response to changing reaction conditions (pressure, temperature, surface coverage, reactant composition, etc.). From the kinetic characteristics derived from multiple experiments performed on a single catalyst sample feature of the structure of the catalytic site can be extracted. Interrogative kinetics uses kinetic interactions between probe molecules and the catalyst surface to construct plausible models of the catalytic site. TAP pulse response experiments are essential for performing 'state-defining' experiments at a constant kinetic state of a catalyst, for distinguishing the details of complex surface transformations, and developing an understanding of the hierarchy of times of surface processes. TAP experiments can be performed on practical and model catalyst, and provide a method of bridging the 'pressure-materials' gap. Another important aspect of interrogative kinetics is the special theoretical analysis of kinetic data. The theory must provide the tools and methodology for rapid primary interpretation of kinetic data, distinguishing of different mechanisms and kinetic cases, and fast extraction of kinetic parameters. Of particular interest is the analysis of data from state defining experiments. Examples will be given in this paper for diffusion, irreversible adsorption/reaction and reversible desorption. The TAP reactor system was originally created to assist the catalyst development process, and is proving to be a powerful tool for unraveling complex catalytic reactions, and other surface processes 13-12]. Recently, we have developed a new experimental apparatus, called a TAP-2 reactor system that significantly extends the capabilities of the TAP experiment. The goal of this paper is to describe the key features of the TAP-2 reactor system that distinguish it from the previous TAP system, to further develop the theoretical foundation of TAP pulse response experiments, to experimentally verify the correct operation of the TAP-2 detection system, and to provide an example of how the TAP-2 system is applied using the methodology of 'interrogative kinetics'. 2. The TAP experiment and TAP reactor systems Transient response experiments can provide a much richer information yield than steady-state experi- 58 J. T Gleaves et al. /Applied Catalysis A: General 160 997) 55-88 ments. Transient response data is the evolved response from a series of transport-kinetic interactions, and contains information about individual steps in a catalytic process. The information is historical in nature, and a key concern is whether the catalytic system is substantially in the same state (i.e., the average structural and kinetic properties are the same) after the measurement as it was before the measurement. In conventional heterogeneous transient kinetic studies, in which a relatively large number of molecules are required for a measurement, the nature of the catalyst (e.g., oxidation state, phase structure, activity, selectivity, etc.) can change as a result of reactions between the catalyst and the gas phase reactants. The kinetic information is obtained from measurements of gas phase concentrations, and the sensitivity of these measurements is limited by the ability to measure changes in concentration. Thus a major drawback of conventional transient response experiments is the severity of the perturbation to the catalytic system caused by the transient input. Under these conditions it is very difficult to control the state of the catalyst surface and bulk, and to achieve reproducible results. Although transient experiments have the potential to give significantly more information than steady-state experiments, they are not as commonly performed. One of the most important features that distinguishes TAP reactor systems from other kinetic installations is the TAP pulse response experiment. This experiment is a unique type of transient response experiment performed by injecting a narrow gas pulse into an evacuated microreactor. TAP pulse response experiments involve a very small number of molecules in comparison to conventional transient response experiments. In a TAP pulse response experiment the injected gas molecules as well as any product molecules formed by chemical reactions are transported through the reactor by Knudsen diffusion. An important characteristic of the Knudsen flow regime is that the diffusivities of the individual components of a gas mixture are independent of the gas composition of the mixture. TAP pulse response experiments use a different experimental strategy to extract kinetic parameters than the more traditional strategies employed in steady-state experiments or in surface science experiments. In steady-state experiments the kinetic information is extracted from the transport-kinetics data by experimentally eliminating the effects of transport (e.g., decreasing the size of catalyst pellets, increasing the gas flow rate, etc.). In surface science experiments the gas phase is eliminated so that only surface interactions are observed. In TAP pulse response experiments gas transport is not eliminated. The pulse response data provides information on the transport and kinetic parameters. Because the transport characteristics of any component are constant with respect to composition, a special theory can be constructed to obtain both kinetic and transport characteristics. The critical difference between the TAP and TAP-2 reactor systems is the positioning of the microreactor and the detector that measures the reactor effluent. In the TAP-2 system, the two devices are physically much closer, and as result the detection efficiency or sensitivity of the TAP-2 system is much higher. The TAP-2 system can perform pulse response experiments using much smaller input pulses than the original TAP system, and temperature programmed experiments at vacuum conditions more effectively than the original system. It possible to perform quantitative kinetics on a larger number of catalytic systems with the TAP-2 reactor because pulse response experiments can be performed at lower pressures where Knudsen diffusion is the transport mechanism. Using the TAP-2 system, TAP pulse response experiments can be state-defining experiments. With the TAP-2 system a typical Knudsen pulse contains .;: 1013 molecules or 10-1moles. Assuming a catalyst sample has a surface area of 10 M2/g, a single pulse would be equivalent to 1/1 000000 of the total surface area of a 0.1 g sample. If the active surface area of the catalyst comprises a reasonable fraction (e.g., >0.1 %) of the total surface area of the catalyst, then a single pulse will have a negligible effect on the active surface. In this case, the transient input in a TAP pulse response experiment causes a very small perturbation to the catalytic system, and the system remains substantially in the same state after the measurement as it was before the measurement. Consequently, the kinetic characteristics correspond to a constant kinetic state of the catalyst. Whenever the number of reactant molecules in a pulse is significantly smaller than the number of active species then the TAP pulse response experiment can be state defining. The ideal kinetic installation for performing interrogative kinetics should possess the following fea- J. T Cleaves et al. /Applied Catalysis A: General 160 (1997) 55-88 tures: (1) high time resolution; (2) real-time data acquisition, and (3) the ability for multikinetic analysis (i.e., the ability to perform kinetic measurements in a variety of kinetic regimes on a single catalyst sample, and the ability to rapidly switch from one kinetic regime to another). In addition, it is desirable that the system be capable of supporting complimentary in situ spectroscopic experiments. The TAP-2 system possesses the essential features required for an interrogative kinetic study. A single catalyst sample can be studied over an extended pressure range from atmospheric pressures to high vacuum conditions. A variety of transient response and steady-flow experiments can be performed without exposing the sample to the atmosphere. Reaction products can be monitored in real-time and the catalyst can be cycled rapidly from one kinetic regime to another. This last feature decreases the time required to obtain data, eliminates some experimental uncertainties (e.g., whether the catalyst surface is in the same state during each experiment), and improves the chances of developing accurate correlations. By combining results from complimentary transient response and steadyflow experiments, unique insights regarding the catalytic reaction mechanism and the nature of the active catalytic site can be gained. The types of transient experiments include high-speed pulse experiments (e.g., TAP pump-probe experiments, multipulse experiments, etc.), step-function experiments for isotopic switching, TPD experiments, and TPR experiments. Most experiments can be programmed using mouse-driven computer software that automatically collects data, and keeps track of experimental conditions when an experiment is running. Transient response experiments Reactant gases can be introduced into the microreactor in a variety of transient formats at both vacuum and atmospheric pressures. Typical transient formats include introducing pulses in sets of varying length and pulse rate from one or two pulse valves, or in a pump-probe format alternating between two of the four valves. When the system is operated in the highpressure mode, pulses can be introduced at a high repetition rate (>10 pps) to create a step response. Reaction products are analyzed in real-time using the QMS operated in either the TRANSIENT or the SCAN mode. The choice of the QMS operating mode is determined by the time response of the experiment. Generally, high-speed vacuum pulse-response experiments require the TRANSIENT mode. Step-response experiments can be analyzed using the SCAN mode. Typical pulse intensities in vacuum experiments range from 101; to 1017 molecules/pulse, with pulse widths of 2501ts, and pulse rates between 1 and 50 pulses/s. Sequential product intensity variations can be associated with changes in reactant conversion rates, and product production rates. These changes can also be associated with changes in the catalyst (e.g., reduction of an oxide surface or the poisoning of a surface by deposited carbon). Fig. 5 illustrates the inputs and transient responses in a TAP pump-probe experiment. In this case, different reactant mixtures are introduced sequentially from separate pulse valves. The output transient response spectrum now contains product pulses coinciding with both valve inputs. For example, one valve may contain a hydrocarbon-inert gas mixture, and the other valve an oxygen-inert gas mixture. By alternately pulsing the hydrocarbon and oxygen mixtures the catalyst surface can be maintained in a relatively constant oxidation state without exposing the hydrocarbon to gas phase oxygen. The pump-probe format can also be used to investigate the dynamics of surface processes involving reactive adspecies. For example, if reactant A forms a transient adspecies that reacts with reactant B, the rate of disappearance of A can be followed by changing the interval between A and B inputs. The pump-probe format is also useful for investigating catalyst activation. In this case, one pulse-valve is used to introduce the activating agent, and the other pulse-valve is used to introduce a reactive probe to monitor the state of the catalyst surface. By monitoring a number of reaction products, changes in activity and selectivity can be observed, and correlated with the incorporation of the activating species. Theory and modeling of TAP pulse response data The grist of TAP theory is vacuum pulse response data. The goal of TAP theory is to interpret this data, and to reveal the complex catalytic mechanism; i.e., (1) to determine the totality of typical processes that make up the complex mechanism, (2) to find the parameters of these processes, and (3) to develop a model of the catalytic center, and the complex catalytic reaction. From the perspective of interrogative kinetics, TAP theory is concerned with analyzing state-defining experiments, particularly with experiments that provide the parameters of diffusion, irreversible adsorption/reaction, and reversible adsorption. These parameters are characteristic of the physical and kinetic state of a catalyst sample. It is instructive to compare the state-defining kinetic parameter, or `kinetic parameter of the catalyst' (KPC) that is obtained in TAP pulse response experiments with the well-known steady-state kinetic parameter `turnover number' [13]. The turnover number, or the `turnover frequency', or the `site time yield' is defined as the rate of reaction per number of active sites. The traditional method of determining a turnover number requires two different types of experiments. The first type involves a determination of the steady-state rate of catalytic reaction. This experiment is performed under conditions in which the disturbing influences of mass and heat transfer are eliminated. The second experiment is an adsorption experiment that provides an estimation of the number of active sites. From a rigorous point of view, the second experiment provides information on the number of adsorption sites, and there is always the question of whether the number of adsorption sites is same as the number of active catalytic sites. The determination of the KPC involves measuring the TAP pulse response of an inert gas and that of a reactant. In this case, the experiments are performed at the same reaction conditions, and on the same catalyst sample in the same kinetic state (for a discussion about the phenomenological kinetic rate equation at constant J.T Cleaves et al./Applied Catalysis A: General 160 (19971 55-88 catalyst composition see [14]). The inert gas response provides a measure of the transport characteristics of the catalyst in the absence of reaction, and contains information about the number of gas-surface encounters. The reactant gas response provides a measure of the transport-kinetics characteristics of the catalyst, and contains information on the number of effective encounters. By combining both measurements it is possible, on the basis of theoretical analysis, to eliminate the contribution of transport, and to obtain the values of the KPC. Examples of this technique are given in this paper. The transport-kinetics interactions that occur in TAP pulse response experiments can be described using either a stochastic or a deterministic approach. Currently, there are two deterministic models based on partial-differential equations. The simplest model, called a 'one-zone-model' is used to describe a reactor that is completely filled with a single catalyst sample, or with a uniform mixture of catalyst and inert material. The more complex, 'three-zone-model', is used when the catalyst sample is sandwiched between two zones that contain an inert material. In the following section, a detailed analysis of the one-zone-model is presented. Special attention is focused on distinguishing typical processes (i.e., finding their patterns or finger prints), and extracting transport and kinetic parameters. Following the discussion of the onezone-model, comparative results obtained with a three-zone-model are presented, and the correspondence between the two models is discussed. 5.1. Fingerprints of TAP kinetics for adsorption/ reaction and desorption Transient response curves from a `one-zone-reac- tor' are characterized by four `fingerprints' that arise from differences in the rates of adsorption and desorption. Using these fingerprints different cases can be distinguished. 1. Inside-flow. In this case, the flow curve is situated inside the standard diffusion curve, and is the fingerprint for irreversible adsorption/reaction. 2. Intersection. In this case, the flow curve crosses the standard diffusion curve, and is the fingerprint for reversible adsorption. 3. Double-hump curve. The transformation can be viewed as dividing the ordinate and multiplying the abscissa of each point of the standard curve by a positive coefficient. TAP-2 application - the selective oxidation of n-butane The selective oxidation of n-butane to malefic anhydride (MA) over vanadium phosphorus oxide (VPO) catalysts is arguably one of the most important heterogeneous selective oxidation reactions. It has been studied extensively for the past 20 years, and over one thousand papers and patents have been published on the VPO catalyst system. Currently, it is the only industrially practiced heterogeneous selective oxidation reaction involving an alkane, and is therefore the prototype for other alkane selective oxidation reactions. From a fundamental perspective the oxidation of n-butane over VPO catalysts is an extremely rich catalytic reaction involving the transfer of 14 electrons, the fissure of eight CH bonds, the addition of three oxygen atoms, and a ring closure. Among the various techniques used to study this reaction, the TAP-2 system has proved to be extremely useful for unraveling the complex chemistry, and revealing the nature of the catalytic center. This section presents key results from recent TAP-2 studies of n-butane oxidation over VPO catalysts that illustrate the methodology of `interrogative kinetics'. Although there is extensive evidence [20,21-25] that (VO)ZPzO7 is the active-selective phase in VPO catalysts, it is not clear how the (VO)ZP207 lattice supplies the seven oxygen atoms needed to convert nbutane to MA. The reaction may involve oxygen adspecies adsorbed at vanadium surface sites, and relatively little bulk lattice oxygen, and a number of studies [26] indicate a close correspondence between the number of surface vanadium atoms, and the amount of active oxygen. Other studies [27,28], however, indicate that the amount of active oxygen can significantly exceed the amount of surface oxygen and must include some bulk oxygen. A number of researchers [29,30] have proposed that other crystalline phases are involved in the VPO system, and suggest that the active sites for MA production are situated at the interface of two phases. These contradicting results suggest that there may be more than one catalytic mechanism and more than one type of active center involved in the VPO system, and that the state of the catalytic surface determines which mechanism dominates. Steady-state kinetic studies of n-butane oxidation over VPO catalysts [31,32,33] have yielded different rate expressions and kinetic parameters. Literature values for the activation energy of n-butane conversion over VPO catalysts range from 11 to 27 kcal/mol. The observed differences in kinetic dependencies may J.T Gleaves et al. /Applied Catalvsis A: General 160 (1997) 55-88 83 be related to differences in catalyst composition, catalyst structure, catalyst oxidation state, etc. The differences in kinetic dependencies from these previous experiments provide no unique information, however, since the various modifications and states of the catalyst cannot be directly compared. From the perspective of interrogative kinetics the problem is to relate changes in kinetic dependencies to changes in the catalyst. The methodology involves a systematic alteration of the state of a catalyst and measuring the kinetic dependencies of the various states. The advantage of using TAP pulse response experiments is that the kinetic dependencies of the different states can be obtained without significantly altering the states. 7.1. 1rret~ersible reaction of n-butane The kinetics of n-butane conversion over VPO catalysts in the absence of gas phase oxygen can be studied by performing a series of TAP pulse response experiments. TAP reactor systems are being used in fundamental and applied studies: to reveal the mechanisms of industrial and model catalytic reactions; to assist in the design of new catalyst; to test the industry catalysts; to make the recommendations concerning new regimes for industrial reactors. At the risk of being taken for prophets we will make some predictions regarding future developments this area. 8.1. TAP-2 modifications Future TAP system research will be focused on combining the TAP-2 experimental apparatus with other physical tools (IR and Raman spectroscopy) to allow both the gas phase and the catalyst to be monitored together. The key idea is to combine TAP pulse response, and other transient experiments with in situ spectroscopic techniques. These complimentary experiments will be incorporated into modified TAP systems, and used to simultaneously investigate surface adspecies, desorbing reaction products, and the catalyst structure during catalytic reactions. Currently, there are few examples of simultaneous monitoring of surface and gas species using transient response techniques. By combining these approaches to simultaneously observe different aspects of the catalytic process in real-time more information will be obtained than if the experiments are performed separately. Simultaneous monitoring of different experimental observables also eliminates uncertainties (e.g., whether the catalyst surface is in the same state during each experiment) that arise when performing separate experiments, decreases the time required to obtain data, and improves the chances of developing accurate correlations. From our point of view, the simultaneous observation of surface and gas species is essential for understanding the molecular-level mechanism of complex catalytic reactions. 8.2. TAP-2 and `interrogative kinetics' We believe that interrogative kinetics represents a promising new methodology for exploring complex catalytic systems. It is reasonable to predict that as the TAP experiment continues to be developed and applied, the methodology of `interrogative kinetics' will be refined. We anticipate the development of new combinations of state-defining and state-altering experiments. The combination of these experiments can provide information about changes in a catalyst, and the nature of the catalyst during the reaction. Special attention will be paid to experiments that test the reproducibility of a catalyst. We also anticipate that future theoretical studies will provide new fingerprints and procedures. The methodology of interrogative kinetics seeks to build an understanding of structure-activity relationships by J. An important advantage of this approach is that it can provide fundamental information regarding structure-activity relationships while leading directly to an improved state of a catalyst.
